Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Community trait responses to environmental variation: assessing the roles of species turnover, genetic differentiation, and phenotypic plasticity
Award.AbstractNarration:
Climate change and other anthropogenic influences are causing dramatic alterations in the structure and composition of plant communities worldwide. Predicting these changes is a critical challenge for ecologists. How plants respond to changing environmental conditions depends on their ecological features or traits, such as leaf and stem characteristics and height. Changes in the environment may favor plants with different traits than the ones currently present in a given site, and plant communities may respond to these changes in multiple ways. First, there may be increasing presence and relative abundance of species with traits adapted to the new conditions (species turnover). Second, species already present in the site may adapt through genetic changes in their traits (evolution). Third, individuals may be able to adjust their traits in order to fit the new environment (phenotypic plasticity). The goal of this research is to disentangle the roles of species turnover, evolution, and phenotypic plasticity in community responses to environmental change, using old-field plant communities of eastern North America as a study system. The investigators will combine field surveys of old-field communities from southern Ontario to northern Florida with transplant experiments to determine how plant traits respond to variation in climate and soils.

The knowledge gained through this research will improve our ability to predict changes in biodiversity and ecosystem functioning in response to future climate change, issues of profound importance to society. The project will generate valuable data for climate-vegetation models, which will be shared with research groups worldwide via online databases. The project will also facilitate collaborations with scientists and land managers at research stations and nature preserves across eastern North America and provide ecological data that will inform conservation, education, and future research at these sites. The accessibility of old-field ecosystems will provide excellent opportunities to link research with education. The investigators will lead local middle school students on nature walks through research sites, introducing them to the biodiversity of old-field communities while teaching ecosystem concepts. The study will also allow undergraduate students to participate in research in the field, lab, and greenhouse and develop independent thesis projects.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A major challenge for ecologists and society this centure is to understand and predict how ecological communities will respond to changing environments. To address this challenge, one approach is to view communities through the lens of functional traits, the characteristics of organisms that influence how they respond to and affect their environment. Because specific environmental conditions favor individuals with specific traits, understanding the links between traits and environment offers a way to predict how communities will respond to changing environments. If the environment changes in a way that favors individuals with certain trait values, the community may either respond through increases in the abundance of species with those trait values (i.e. species turnover), or through trait adjustments within the species already present via adaptive evolution or phenotypic plasticity (i.e. intraspecific trait variation).

This project provided one of the most thorough assessments to date of how the traits of plant communities respond to variation in the environment, and how species turnover and intraspecific variation contribute to these responses. By examining traits of plant communities at an unprecedented spatial extent (1200 km) in old-field grasslands in eastern North America, we were able to address unresolved questions about the relative role of intraspecific variation in community responses to strong climatic gradients. The results provide novel insights into the role of intraspecific trait variation in the responses of plant communities to environmental variation. Specifically, the findings demonstrate that intraspecific responses to climate and edaphic factors contribute significantly to community-level changes, challenging traditional assumptions in community ecology. Moreover, by examining patterns on unprecedently large spatial scales and a variety of environmental contexts, the results allow greater generalization about the role of intraspecific trait variation in plant communities.

Our findings help bridge gaps between plant community ecology and evolutionary biology by integrating patterns and processes occurring at the community and species levels and using functional traits as a "common currency" to assess diversity and responses to environmental variation across levels of biological organization. In addition, data collected for this project and shared through the TRY plant trait database have been and continue to be used by researchers from around the world in projects from various disciplines, such as ecosystem ecology, evolution, climate change research, and vegetation modelling.

Results from the project provide information that will improve predictions of plant community responses to climate change and other environmental change, an issue of profound societal significance. Specifically, our findings that plant communities respond to strong spatial climatic gradients primarily through species turnover rather than intraspecific trait adjustments suggest that predicted future climate change will result in strong changes in species composition of plant communities in the eastern United States.
